case_name: State of Orissa v. Tulloch & Co. Private Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 561 and 562 of 1962 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No. 561 and 562 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated April 18, 1961 of Orissa High Court in O.J.Cs. Nos. 142 and 144 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1961, of the Orissa High Court in O. J. Cs. Nos. 142 and 144 of 1960.

facts.text: Each respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 before Orissa High Court for writ of mandamus against State of Orissa and Administrator of Orissa Mining Areas Development Fund.

anchor.surface_text: Each of the respondents in ,the two appeals filed a petition before the High Court of Orissa under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for the issue of a writ of mandamus

facts.text: Respondent Tulloch & Co. Private Ltd. is a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act and works a manganese mine in Orissa under lease granted by State under Mines & Minerals Development Regulation Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The res- pondent Tulloch Co. Private Ltd.--a companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, works a manganese mine in the State of Orissa under a lease

facts.text: Orissa Legislature passed Orissa Mining Areas Development Fund Act, 1952 (Orissa Act 27 of 1952), constituting mining areas and empowering levy of fee on percentage of value of mined ore.

anchor.surface_text: While the respondent was. thus working these mines, the State Legislature of Orissa passed an Act called the Orissa Mining Areas Development Fund Act 1952

facts.text: State Government made demands on respondent on August 1, 1960 for payment of fees under Orissa Act for period July 1957 to March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary steps for bringing these provisions into operation were taken by the State Government who thereafter made demands on the respondent on August 1, 1960

facts.text: Respondent filed O.J.C. 142 of 1960 impugning legality of demand.

anchor.surface_text: When a demand was made for the sum the respondent filed petition 142 of 1960 before the High Court impugning the legality of the demand

facts.text: Orissa High Court allowed writ petitions and issued directions to Administrator.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges allowed the Writ Petition and issued directions to the second appellant in terms of the prayer in the petition.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness under Art. 132(1) as questions involved constitutional interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: As the grounds on which the said demand of the fees was impugned raised substantial questions touching the interpretation of the Constitution the appellants applied

facts.text: High Court held Orissa Act rendered ineffective or superseded by Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957 (Central Act 67 of 1957) from June 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Stated shortly, the companytention which the learned judges of the High Court accepted was that the Orissa Act had been rended ineffective or superseded by a Central enactment-The Mines

facts.text: Central Act 67 of 1957 brought into force on June 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Central Act, which was brought into force as and from June 1, 1953.

facts.text: Orissa Act enacted under Entry 23 State List: Regulation of mines and mineral development subject to List I.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on August 16, 1963 by Ayyangar J.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Reddy and R. Thiagarajan, for the Intervener. August 16, 1963. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Central Act 1957 covers field of regulation and development of minerals, superseding Orissa Act to that extent.

facts.text: Supreme Court followed Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd. v. State of Orissa where Orissa Act upheld against 1948 Central Act but not against post-Constitution declaration.

issues.text: the question regarding the continued operation of the Orissa Mining Areas Development Fund Act (Orissa Act 27 of 1952) and the continued exigibility of the fees leviable from mine-owners under the said enactment

anchor.surface_text: certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution. They raise for consideration the question regarding the continued operation of the Orissa Mining Areas Development Fund Act  Orissa Act 27 of 1952  and the continued exigibility of the fees leviable from mine-owners under the said enactment.

issues.text: whether the extent of control and regulation provided by the Central Act takes within its fold the area or the subject covered by the Orissa Act

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether the extent of control and regulation provided by the Central Act takes within its fold the area or the subject covered by the Orissa Act. Learned Counsel for the appellant raised 4 points  1  that the object and purposes of the Orissa Act and its provisions were quite distinct and different from the object and purposes of the Central Act,

issues.text: whether the object and purposes of the Orissa Act and its provisions were quite distinct and different from the object and purposes of the Central Act, with the result that the two enactments could validly co-exist since they do not cover the same field

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant raised 4 points  1  that the object and purposes of the Orissa Act and its provisions were quite distinct and different from the object and purposes of the Central Act, with the result that the two enactments could validly co-exist since they do not cover the same field.

issues.text: Even if the Central Act might cover the same field in the sense that it would be competent to the Central Government to make rules under the Central Act for the same purposes as the Orissa Act, and the rules when made would overlap the provisions of the Orissa Act, still there was no repugnance between the Central Act and the Orissa Act until such rules were made

anchor.surface_text: 2  Even if the Central Act might cover the same field in the sense that it would be competent to the Central Government to make rules under the Central Act for the same purposes as the Orissa Act, and the rules when made would overlap the provisions of the Orissa Act, still there was no repugnance between the Central Act and the Orissa Act until such rules were made for until then there is no effective and operative Central legislation covering the field occupied by the Orissa Act.

issues.text: The power to enact legislation to levy fees was an independent head of Legislative power under the Constitution under item 96 in the Union list and item 66 in the State List and therefore there was no question of the supersession of the State power under item 66 of the State List by a Central enactment

anchor.surface_text: 3  The power to levy a fee was an independent head of Legislative power under the Constitution under item 96 in the Union list and item 66 in the State List and therefore there was no question of the supersession of the State power under item 66 of the State List by a Central enactment whose source of legislative power is entry 96 of List I and therefore the demand for the fee competently enacted by the State was not superseded by Central legislation even though the latter was covered by Entry 54 of the Union List.

issues.text: In any event, the Central Act was not retrospective or retroactive and could not affect rights which accrued to the State prior to June 1, 1958 on which date the Central Act was brought into force. The fees in regard to which the demands impugned in the case were made had accrued long prior to June 1, 1958 and the demands would therefore be enforceable notwithstanding the disappearance of the State Act subsequent to the date of the accrual of the fee

holdings.text: The Central Act 1957 by its declaration under s.2 withdraws State legislative power under Entry 23 State List to the extent of Union control over regulation and development of minerals, superseding the Orissa Act.

anchor.surface_text: It does not need much argument to realise that to the extent to which the Union Government had taken under its control the regulation and development of minerals so much was withdrawn from the ambit of the power

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament's declaration under Entry 54 List I deprives State competence under Entry 23 State List; results in denudation of power not mere repugnancy.

holdings.text: The declaration in Central Act covers the field of regulation and development of minerals even without rules being framed thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: We are, however, relieved from this task-of detailed examination and discussion of this matter because we consider that it is concluded by a decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. precedent holding declaration sufficient to occupy field without need for rules.

holdings.text: No repugnancy required for supersession; intention to cover whole field by competent superior legislature demonstrates inconsistency.

anchor.surface_text: Repugnancy arises when two enactments both within the competence of the two Legislatures collide and when the Constitution expressly or by necessary implication

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament's legislation evinces intent to cover entire field via s.18(1); State law overborne.

holdings.text: Power to levy fees under Entry 66 State List requires subject-matter competence under Entry 23; fee invalid post-declaration withdrawing competence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fees must relate to 'matters in this List'; subject denudated by Union declaration.

holdings.text: Section 6 General Clauses Act applies to implied repeals/supersession, saving accrued rights, liabilities, and pending proceedings under prior law.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 reads - Where this Act, or any Central Act or Regulation made after the commencement of this Act, repeals any enactment hitherto made or hereafter

holdings.reasoning_summary: Res integra; principle of saving accrued rights/liabilities underlies s.6; applies equally to implied as express repeal as no substantive distinction.

holdings.text: Past liabilities for fees under Orissa Act accrued prior to June 1, 1958 survive supersession by Central Act; demands valid and enforceable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 General Clauses Act saves previous operation, accrued liabilities; fees accrued quarterly pre-supersession.

precedents.citation: The Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd., Ors. v. The State of Orissa and Ors.

anchor.surface_text: The Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd., Ors. v. The State of Orissa and Ors. 1 . There, as here, it was the validity of the demand of the fee under the Orissa Act number under companysideration that was the subject of debate.

precedents.case_name: Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd. v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: The declaration in the Central Act under Entry 54 covers the field of regulation and development of mines and minerals, excluding State legislative competence under Entry 23 even without rules being framed
precedents.cited_holding: If a Central Act contains the requisite declaration under Entry 54, the State Act is ultra vires not due to repugnancy but due to lack of jurisdiction

precedents.citation: The Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd. Ors. v. The State of Orissa and Ors.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place the point is companycluded by the earlier decision of this Court in The Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd. Ors. v. The State of Orissa and Ors. 1  where this Court said In order that the declaration should be effective it is number necessary that rules should be made or enforced

precedents.case_name: Hingir-Rampur Coal Co. Ltd. v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: The declaration by Parliament is effective without the need for rules to be made or enforced
precedents.cited_holding: All that is required is a declaration by Parliament that it is expedient in the public interest to take the regulation and development of mines under the control of the Union

precedents.citation: Ch. Tika Ramji Ors. etc. v. The State of Uttar Pradesh Ors.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this submission reliance was placed on the decision of this Court in Ch. Tika Ramji Ors. etc. v. The State of Uttar Pradesh Ors. 1  and in particular on a passage at p. 432 reading Even assuming that sugarcane was an article or class of articles

precedents.case_name: Tika Ramji v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Repugnancy arises only if a central order is actually issued under the power, not merely on the possibility
precedents.cited_holding: The possibility of an order under section 18-G being issued by the Central Government would not be enough; the existence of such an order would be the essential prerequisite

precedents.citation: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. The State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: It had already been held by this Court in a decision in Keshavan Madhava Menon v. The State of Bombay 1  to which we shall make reference, that when an earlier Act is superseded or rendered null under Art. 13 of the Constitution, numberhing done under the old Act would survive except in respect of past and closed transactions

precedents.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Pre-Constitution laws void under Art. 13 do not affect pending proceedings if valid at commencement
precedents.cited_holding: The Constitution is prospective; Art. 13 does not affect validity of pre-Constitution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Tindak C.J. stated this in Kay v. Goodwin 1  I take the effect of repealing a statute to be to obliterate it as companypletely from the records of the Parliament as if it had never been passed and it must be companysidered as a law that never existed except for the purpose of those actions which were companymenced, prosecuted and companycluded whilst it was an existing law.

precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of repealing a statute is to obliterate it completely as if never passed, except for past actions
precedents.cited_holding: Repeal obliterates the statute as completely from the records as if it had never been passed except for commenced, prosecuted and concluded actions

anchor.surface_text: It was the same idea that was expressed by Lord Tenterden in, Surtees v. Ellison 1  It has long been established that, when an Act of Parliament is repealed, it must be companysidered  except as to transactions past and closed  as if it had never existed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Repealed Act considered as never existing except as to past and closed transactions
precedents.cited_holding: When an Act of Parliament is repealed, it must be considered (except as to transactions past and closed) as if it had never existed

precedents.citation: Trust Mai Lachhmi Sialkori Bradari The Chairman, Amritsar Improvement Trust and Ors.

anchor.surface_text: this point as to the effect of an implied repeal has arisen in a few other cases before this Court but it has been left open see for instance, the judgment in Trust Mai Lachhmi Sialkori Bradari The Chairman, Amritsar Improvement Trust and Ors. 3 .

precedents.case_name: Trust Mai Lachhmi Sialkori Bradari v. Chairman, Amritsar Improvement Trust
precedents.cited_proposition: Point as to effect of implied repeal left open

anchor.surface_text: the principle already enunciated Kay v. Goodwin 1  and Surtees v. Ellison 2  will companytinue to operate.

precedents.cited_proposition: Repeal has drastic effect absent saving clause

precedents.cited_proposition: Repeal has drastic effect absent saving clause

anchor.surface_text: If this were the true position about the effect of the Central Act 67 of 1957 as the liability to pay the fee which was the subject of the notices of the demand had accrued prior to June 1, 1958 it would follow that these notices were valid and the amounts due thereunder could be recovered notwithstanding the disappearance of the Orissa Act by virtue of the superior legislation by the Union Parliament. The appeals would, therefore, be allowed and the Writ Petitions would stand dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; writ petitions dismissed; notices of demand valid and recoverable for fees accrued prior to June 1, 1958
directions: Amounts due recoverable as arrears notwithstanding supersession of Orissa Act
